and figures the skulls of two old males (1) (immania cum cornibus 
capita). the one found on the banks of the Obi, the other from 
a Tundra or treeless barren ground near Beresov on the same 
river. <s>As he was unacquainted with the recent Musk Sheep, he<\s> He 
leaves their specific determination open, merely remarking that 
they agree with Bubalus Caffer in the apposition of the 
horncores. They are however recognized by his contempor[ar]y 
in England, Pennant in 1784 2, as belonging to the recent 
Musk Sheep and as finally affording evidence of the former range 
of that animal over Northern Asia. In 1809 M le Comte 
Roumiantzow found a third head at the embouchement of 
the Yana, with its horns preserved and perfect with the 
exception of its nasals and premaxillaries. M. Ozeretskovsky 
describes it under then name of Bison Musque, and believes 
that the animal lives in Siberia and that possibly it 
may have been exterminated by the same intense cold that 
preserved its bones 3. His two figures also prove that the 
skull belonged to an old male. The next  discovery of the 
animal was made by Capt Beechey in 1826 (4) and subsequently 
by Capt Kellet in 1850) in the remarkable accumulation of bones of 
Elephas primigenius, Reindeer, Elk, Bison and Horse, originally 
found by D<sup>r<\sup> Eschscholtz in the Bay called after his name 
They consist of two fragmentary skulls with horncores of old 
males and the atlas, third dorsal, fifth lumbar, four[th] sacral 
vertebrae, acetabular, pieces of the humerus and one mutilated 
tibia. A large cervical vertebra from the same locality 
is considered by Sir John Richardson to belong to a separate 
species <u>Ovibos Maximus<\u> but the differences do not seem 
to me to be of specific value. The observations of Capt
